journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: The tribological behaviors of disulfide-type triazine derivatives as additives in biodegradable lithium grease

article-meta.aff: School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory for Thin Film and Microfabrication of the Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Tianhui Ren, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Key Laboratory for Thin Film and Microfabrication of the Ministry of Education, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. Email: thren@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Two novel disulfide-type triazine derivatives, 6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(dibutylamino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol) (coded DTBT) and 6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(bis(2-ethylhexyl)amino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol) (coded DTOT), were prepared. A four-ball tester was used to evaluate their tribological performances as anti-wear and extreme-pressure additives in biodegradable lithium grease. The results show that the disulfide-type triazine derivatives possess good friction-reducing properties and excellent anti-wear, extreme-pressure capacities. For further understanding of their tribological behaviors, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and scanning electron microscopy are adopted to analyze the tribofilms generated from these additives in biodegradable lithium grease. The results of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis illustrate that the prepared compounds as additives in biodegradable lithium grease forms a protective film containing FeS, FeS2 (or S-containing organic compounds), Fe2(SO4)3, FeSO4, FeO (or Fe3O4), and N-containing organic compounds on the metal surface during the sliding process.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Grease lubrication is applied practically to the majority of bearings worldwide, and it has become a vital part of most machine components.1 Furthermore, lubricating grease is used as shock absorber, seal, corrosion inhibitor, or even noise suppressant.2–6 In recent years, pollution and environmental health problems have become increasingly important. Therefore, biodegradable grease lubricants used in environmentally sensitive areas have been extensively explored. Lubricating greases are based on synthetic esters because of their high biodegradability, low toxicity, and good thermal stability.7–9 The capabilities of lithium grease include excellent mechanical stability, good water resistance, and reasonably good high-temperature performance, up to 120 ℃.10 However, the use of faster sliding speeds and higher surface loadings in practical operation leads the greases to higher temperatures. To enhance the load-carrying capacity of lubricating greases, appropriate additive is needed.11

Sulfur-containing compounds have been used as additives in lubricants for many years.12 Previous research has shown that the compound with higher sulfur content will have better extreme-pressure performance, but it will also lead to worse chemical corrosion.13,14 So, how to balance the effect between load-carrying capacity and corrosion is of great importance. It has been reported that sulfur-nitrogen compounds which have heterocyclic structure possess excellent extreme-pressure, anti-wear, anti-corrosion, and anti-oxidant properties and high thermal stabilities.15–20 Triazine is one kind of low-toxic heterocyclic compound, and it is expected that the disulfide-type triazine derivatives are effective and anti-corrosive grease additives.

In this article, two novel disulfide-type triazine derivatives were prepared and applied as anti-wear and extreme-pressure additives in biodegradable lithium grease. The tribological behavior of the novel additives in grease were evaluated by a four-ball machine. The surface protective film and the morphology of the wear scar were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM).

sec.title: Materials and sample preparation
sec.p:
Two disulfide-type triazine derivatives were prepared in the laboratory and all the materials used for preparation were analytical grade. The base grease (BG) is biodegradable lithium grease supplied by Lanzhou Petrochemical Company Refinery of China, and its properties are given in Table 1. The balls (Ø 12.7 mm diameter) used in the friction and wear tests are made of GCr15 bearing steel with an HRC of 59–61 hardness. Codes and structures of these additives (DTBT, 6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(dibutylamino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol); DTOT, 6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(bis(2-ethylhexyl)amino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol)) are shown in Figure 1. The prepared products were characterized by elemental analysis (PE 2400-II), 1H-NMR (Varian mercury plus 400), and IR (Paragon-1000 FT-IR). The results of elemental analysis listed in Table 2, 1H-NMR and IR spectra are in good agreement with the target compounds within the experimental error. Figure 1.
Codes and structures of the additives.
Table 1.
Properties of the biodegradable lithium grease.
Items Results Method
Base oil Ester oil
Worked penetration (0.1 mm) 325 GB/T269
Drop point (℃) 170 GB/T3498
Corrosive (copper strip, 100 ℃, 24 h) Pass GB/T7326
Oil separation (100 ℃, 30 h) (%) 5.86 SH/T0324
Evaporation loss (100 ℃, 22 h) (%) 0.17 GB/T7325
Biodegradability >70%
Table 2.
The elemental analysis results of target compounds.
Sample C (wt%) H (wt%) N (wt%) S (wt%)
DTBT 48.37 (48.71)a 7.22 (7.01)a 20.60 (20.67)a 23.50 (23.62)a
DTOT 59.87 (59.53)a 9.05 (9.14)a 14.23 (14.60)a 16.80 (16.71)a
DTBT: (6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(dibutylamino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol); DTOT: 6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(bis(2-ethylhexyl)amino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol). a
Calculated value.

sec.title: Friction and wear test
sec.p: The friction and wear tests were carried out at room temperature on a MRS-10 four-ball test machine made in Jinan Testing Machine Factory of China. All the friction and wear tests were conducted at a rotating speed of 1450 r/min and loads of 98, 196, 294, 392, 490 N with test duration of 30 min. The friction coefficients were automatically measured and recorded every 10 s by a computer connected to the four-ball machine. The wear scar diameters (WSDs) of the three lower balls were measured by an optical microscope with an accuracy ±0.01 mm, and the results were averaged and cited as the WSDs reported in the article. For the extreme-pressure tests, the maximum non-seizure loads (PB values) and the weld loads (PD values) were obtained by a MS-800 four-ball machine made in Xiamen Test Machine Factory of China. The PB values and PD values tests were conducted at a rotating speed of 1760 r/min with test duration of 10 s. Chinese national standard GB3142-82 similar to ASTM D-2783 is adopted for the tests.

sec.title: Worn surface analysis
sec.p: XPS was conducted with a PHI-5702 multifunctional X-ray electron spectrometer. The upper ball used for XPS analysis was washed ultrasonically with petroleum ether and dried after testing at an additive concentration of 5.0 wt% under 392 N. The Mg-Kα radiation was used as the excitation source with pass energy of 29.35 eV. The binding energy of C1s (284.6 eV) was used as the reference. The JSM-5600LV SEM analysis was used to study the rubbed surface morphology in the worn steel surfaces.

sec.title: Anti-wear performance
sec.p:
Generally, the tribological characteristic of certain lubricating grease can be evaluated by the combination of its anti-wear performance and friction-reducing performance.2–4 Figure 2 shows the anti-wear performances of the lubricating grease samples containing DTBT and DTOT at different additive concentrations under 392 N. It can be seen that both DTBT and DTOT can markedly improve the anti-wear property of grease, whereas the DTOT is better than DTBT at the same concentration. The possible reason is that the additive with longer chain can form thicker film on the surface of steel ball. In addition, higher additive concentration results in smaller WSD. This is due to the protective film formed by the additives and its decomposers on the sliding surface under the boundary lubrication conditions. Figure 3 shows the anti-wear performances of the BG and lubricating grease samples containing 5.0 wt% DTBT and 5.0 wt% DTOT at different loads. The results indicate that the anti-wear performances of grease samples containing DTBT and DTOT are much better than that of the BG at the applied load of 98–490 N, and DTOT exhibits better anti-wear performances than DTBT below the load of 392 N. This result has a close relation with the chain length of additive molecule, and the long-chain molecule (DTOT) is more suitable than the short-chain molecule (DTBT) for wear reducing. Figure 2.
Effect of the concentration of additives on WSD (four-ball machine, 392 N, rotary speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).
WSD: wear scar diameter.
Figure 3.
Effect of the applied load on WSD (four-ball machine, additive concentration of 5.0 wt%, rotary speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).
WSD: wear scar diameter.

sec.title: Friction-reducing performance
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the friction-reducing performances of the grease samples containing DTBT and DTOT at various additive concentrations along with the BG at the load of 392 N. It can be seen that DTOT is suitable for using at lower concentration (about 1.0 wt%), and DTBT is more effective in reducing friction than DTOT at higher additive concentrations (above 2.0 wt%). DTBT shows excellent and stable friction-reducing performances at concentration of 1.0–5.0 wt% in lithium grease, and DTOT performs well. It is known that the friction coefficient has a close relation with the thickness of the adsorption film or reaction film formed on the rubbing surface. With the increasing of additive’s concentration, thicker film is generated, thus friction coefficient gets lower. Figure 5 shows the friction-reducing performances of the grease samples containing 5.0 wt% DTBT and 5.0 wt% DTOT at various loads along with the BG. DTBT shows excellent friction-reducing performances at applied load of 196–392 N in lithium grease and DTOT does well below the load of 392 N but fails at higher loads. Both DTBT and DTOT perform the best friction-reducing behavior at the load of 294 N. Figure 4.
Effect of the concentration of additives on friction coefficient (four-ball machine, 392 N, rotary speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).
Figure 5.
Effect of the applied load on friction coefficient (four-ball machine, additive concentration of 5.0 wt%, rotary speed of 1450 r/min, duration of 30 min).

sec.title: Extreme-pressure performance
sec.p:
Engines and gear systems often perform under extreme-pressure conditions, where both the operating temperatures and loads are higher than common conditions. Generally, the purpose of the extreme-pressure additive is to provide added wear protection and anti-seizing properties to both the metallic surface and the lubricant under higher loads and higher temperatures, and sulfur is one of the most widely used elements in extreme-pressure lubricant additives.21 The PB value of the BG and the BG containing 5.0 wt% DTBT and 5.0 wt% DTOT, respectively, are shown in Figure 6. In comparison with the BG, the PB value is increased using these derivatives as extreme-pressure additives at a given concentration, and the derivative DTOT is better than DTBT. In particular, the PB value of DTOT which is 667 N is twice of the BG. This indicates that both DTBT and DTOT have good extreme-pressure property. The PB value of DTOT which contains longer chain in molecular structure is higher than that of DTBT, suggesting that the additive containing longer chain possesses better load-carrying capacities in grease. The possible reason is that the additive with longer chain is more compatible with the BG, so it is easier to adsorb on the metal surface and form a thicker protective film on the surface. The PD value of the BG and the BG containing 5.0 wt% DTBT and 5.0 wt% DTOT, respectively, are shown in Figure 7. It is obvious that the two additives equally and greatly enhance the PD value in comparison with that of the BG. Figure 6.
The maximum non-seizure loads (PB values) of additives (four-ball machine, additive concentration of 5.0 wt%, rotary speed of 1760 r/min, 10 s).
Figure 7.
The weld loads (PD values) of additives (four-ball machine, additive concentration of 5.0 wt%, rotary speed of 1760 r/min, 10 s).

sec.title: Surface analysis by XPS
sec.p:
In order to explore the lubrication mechanism of the additive in biodegradable lithium grease, XPS analysis of the worn surface was carried out. The binding energy of some standard compounds containing Fe, O, S, and N was listed in Table 3 for comparison, which could be obtained in NIST XPS database. Table 3.
Binding energy of some standard compounds containing Fe, O, S, and N.
Compounds Binding energy (eV) Compounds Binding energy (eV)
Nitride N-containing organic N1s (399.7) Sulfur S-containing organic S2p (162.3)
Oxide of iron Fe2O3 Fe2p (711.3); O1s (529.8) Sulfate of iron FeSO4 Fe2p (713.6); S2p (168.7); O1s (532.3)
Fe3O4 Fe2p (709.4); O1s (529.7) Fe2(SO4)3 Fe2p (713.3); S2p (169.1); O1s (531.0)
FeO Fe2p (709.6); O1s (530.1) Sulfide of iron FeS Fe2p (710.3); S2p (160.8)
FeS2 Fe2p (706.6); S2p (162.4)

Figure 8 shows the XPS spectra of the tribochemical films generated from the synthesized additive DTBT at the concentration 5.0 wt% under 392 N. The XPS peaks of S2p appear at 169.24, 168.92, 162.57, and 161.01 eV. By comparison with the standard values summarized in Table 3 and combined with Figure 8(a) and (b), they belong to Fe2(SO4)3, FeSO4, FeS2, and FeS. The reason maybe that the additive molecule decomposed to produce R–S·under boundary lubrication conditions, which can easily interact with the surface to form the film containing sulfate, FeS2, and FeS. In case of oxygen, combining with the binding energy of Fe2p (Figure 8(b)), the iron oxide should be FeO, suggesting that iron in the film is in a state of oxidation. For the element of N, the binding energy of N1s is at 399.43 eV, indicating that N element is in organic state and N in the additive did not undergo tribochemical reaction with the frictional metal surface. In the molecular structure of DTBT, it contains –N = C– structure and –N–C– structure. So, it can be known that there is a strong adsorption of additive molecule or its decomposed products on the worn surface. Figure 8.
XPS spectra of typical elements on worn steel surfaces (DTBT 5.0 wt%).
XPS: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy; DTBT: (6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(dibutylamino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol).

Figure 9 shows the XPS spectra of the tribochemical films generated from the synthesized additive DTOT at the concentration 5.0 wt% under 392 N. The XPS peaks of S2p appear at 169.12, 168.51, 162.33, and 161.02 eV. By comparison with the standard values summarized in Table 3 and combined with Figure 9(e) and (f), they belong to Fe2(SO4)3, FeSO4, S-containing organic, and FeS. S-containing organic on the surface may be due to the longer chain of DTOT, so the molecule or its decomposed products adsorbed on the surface during the sliding process more easily and stably than DTBT. In case of oxygen, combining with the binding energy of Fe2p (Figure 9(f)), the iron oxide should be Fe3O4. For the element of N, similar to Figure 8, the binding energy of N1s is at 400.06 eV, indicating that N element is still in organic state. Figure 9.
XPS spectra of typical elements on worn steel surfaces (DTOT 5.0 wt%).
XPS: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy; DTOT: 6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(bis(2-ethylhexyl)amino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol).

It is known that mercaptyl radical could be generated from the breakage of S–S bond. Owing to the conjugation structure of triazine ring, disulfides with triazine structure may have weak S–S bond due to the stability of the triazinyl mercaptyl radical by resonance. And the longer alkyl-chain molecule DTOT is more compatible with the BG, so it is easier and more stable to adsorb on the metal surface and form relatively thicker protective layer. During the sliding process, the C–S bond breaks and generates inorganic sulfur-containing substances. On the other hand, the inner layer can be protected from being quickly rubbed away by the outer layer and can maintain on the sliding surface for a longer time, thus it avoids the direct contact of the surfaces and effectively restraint wear. So, with a thicker reaction and adsorption layer, the additive DTOT shows better tribological performances.

From the above analysis, it can come to a conclusion that tribological reaction occurred between the additives and the metal surface during the friction process, accompanied by the adsorption of the decomposed additives, and a film consisting of sulfide, disulfide (or S-containing organic compounds), sulfate, oxide, and N-containing organic compounds was formed.

sec.title: SEM micrograph
sec.p:
Figure 10 shows the SEM morphology (×100, ×400) of the worn surfaces. It is seen that the worn surface lubricated by BG shows wide and deep furrows, but the scuffing on the worn surface lubricated by BG containing the novel additive DTBT or DTOT is abated obviously with only shallow scratch. In particular, the worn surface lubricated by BG containing DTOT seems extremely smooth with narrow and shallow grooves, which indicates that the corresponding boundary lubricating films formed by BG containing the novel additives have better strength than that formed by BG alone. The morphological features are in agreement with the corresponding friction and wear behavior. Figure 10.
SEM micrographs of worn surface lubricated with: (a) BG, ×100; (b) 5.0 wt% DTBT in BG, ×100; (c) 5.0 wt% DTOT in BG, ×100; (d) BG, ×400; (e) 5.0 wt% DTBT in BG, ×400; (f) 5.0 wt% DTOT in BG, ×400 (load 392 N, speed 1450 r/min, duration 30 min).
SEM: scanning electron microscopy; BG: base grease; DTBT: (6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(dibutylamino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol); and DTOT: 6,6'-disulfanediylbis(4-(bis(2-ethylhexyl)amino)-1,3,5-triazine-2-thiol).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
From the above results, we can draw the following conclusions:
The two synthesized disulfide-type triazine derivatives applied as additive in biodegradable grease possess excellent anti-wear properties which increase with the increasing of the additive concentration, and the derivative DTOT is more effective than the derivative DTBT. For the improvement of the friction-reducing properties, the derivative DTBT is more effective than derivative DTOT at higher additive concentrations, and DTOT fails at the applied load of 490 N.
Both derivative DTBT and derivative DTOT are effective extreme-pressure additives. When the additive concentration is 5.0 wt%, DTOT with longer alkyl-chain is much better than DTBT in enhancing the maximum non-seizure load (PB value), and both of them can largely and equally enhance the weld load (PD value).
Absorption and tribochemical reactions have been occurred on the worn surface lubricated by the synthesized additives to form a complex boundary lubrication film. The film generated by DTBT contains Fe2(SO4)3, FeSO4, FeS2, FeS, FeO, and N-containing organic compounds, and the film of DTOT consists of Fe2(SO4)3, FeSO4, FeS, Fe3O4, S-containing organic compounds, and N-containing organic compounds.
The SEM morphology of the worn surfaces can match anti-wear and friction-reducing properties.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant no. 20872092).
